elements.content: By associating rigidity and flexibility within the organic building blocks, we have synthesized four new metal–organic coordination polymers, formulated as {Co(ADA)(bpbix)} n ·nH2O (1), {Co(ADC)(bpbix)} n (2), {Co(ADA)(bpim)} n ·nH2O (3), and {Co2(ADC)2(bpim)} n (4), by using the adamantane based flexible dicarboxylate ligand H2ADA and rigid dicarboxylate ligand H2ADC along with flexible bis-imidazole linker, bpbix and rigid bis-imidazole linker, bpim as coligands (where H2ADA = 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid; H2ADC = 1,3-adamantanedicarboxylic acid; bpbix = 4,4′-bis((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)biphenyl; bpim = 4,4′-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)biphenyl). Compounds 1–4 have been characterized by routine elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In the crystal structures of these compounds 1–4, diverse architectures, have been observed, formation of which is facilitated by the conformation rigidity and flexibility of the ligands. The role of the interchanging between flexibility and rigidity of both the adamantine- and bis-imidazole-based ligands in assessing the diversity in the resulting architectures has been discussed. In addition, temperature-dependent magnetic studies for the compounds 1, 3, and 4 have been described.

elements.content: The self-assembly processes leading to the formation of coordination polymers have been studied by interplaying between rigidity and flexibility of the adamantane based dipodal acid and bis-imidazole linker in a Co(II) metal−ligand system. In this context, four compounds, synthesized from (flexible, flexible), (rigid, flexible), (flexible, rigid), and (rigid, rigid) binary linkers, have been demonstrated.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly processes leading to the formation of coordination polymers have been studied by interplaying between rigidity and flexibility of the adamantane based dipodal acid and bis-imidazole linker in a Co(II) metal-ligand system. In this context, four compounds, synthesized from (flexible, flexible), (rigid, flexible), (flexible, rigid), and (rigid, rigid) binary linkers, have been demonstrated.

elements.content: Because of a diverse range of aesthetically pleasing structures, design and synthesis of metal–organic framework (MOF) containing compounds or coordination polymers (CPs) are becoming one of the most rapidly developing research area in chemical and material sciences. In recent time, the chemistry of MOF-compounds has been explored in different interdisciplinary subjects because of their potential applications in diverse area, for example, gas adsorption and separation, catalysis, biomedical applications, sensing, host–guest induced separation etc. A MOF structure is simply interpreted as a network, portrayed by nodes (metal ions) linked together via linkers. The topology of the resultant network is reliant on the coordination environment of the nodes and characteristics of the linkers, such as flexibility or rigidity, coordination modes, no of coordination sites, geometry of the spacer, etc. Thus, the vigilant selection of the organic ligands is requisite to accomplish the desired topologies, which is still a provocative challenge to synthetic inorganic chemists. The subject of crystal engineering has provided knowledge in designing thumb rules to tune the topology, thereby, in designing the predicted architectures with functional applications. A minute change in skeleton of the linker has a hefty effect on functional property of the resulting material. Du et al. reported that the simple change in position of coordinating atom can shift the coordination sites of the ligand, thereby, can enhance the surface polarization of framework severely to increase the selectivity for CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Because of a diverse range of aesthetically pleasing structures, design and synthesis of metal-organic framework (MOF) containing compounds or coordination polymers (CPs) are becoming one of the most rapidly developing research area in chemical and material sciences. In recent time, the chemistry of MOF-compounds has been explored in different interdisciplinary subjects because of their potential applications in diverse area, for example, gas adsorption and separation, catalysis, biomedical applications, sensing, host-guest induced separation etc. A MOF structure is simply interpreted as a network, portrayed by nodes (metal ions) linked together via linkers. The topology of the resultant network is reliant on the coordination environment of the nodes and characteristics of the linkers, such as flexibility or rigidity, coordination modes, no of coordination sites, geometry of the spacer, etc. Thus, the vigilant selection of the organic ligands is requisite to accomplish the desired topologies, which is still a provocative challenge to synthetic inorganic chemists. The subject of crystal engineering has provided knowledge in designing thumb rules to tune the topology, thereby, in designing the predicted architectures with functional applications. A minute change in skeleton of the linker has a hefty effect on functional property of the resulting material. Du et al. reported that the simple change in position of coordinating atom can shift the coordination sites of the ligand, thereby, can enhance the surface polarization of framework severely to increase the selectivity for CO2.

elements.content: Metal organic frameworks/coordination polymer can be categorized into two major classes: rigid and flexible/dynamic. In principle, the use of geometrically rigid organic building block allows prediction of final architecture with certain topologies having comparatively high stability. The concerned materials usually exhibit thermally robust porous frameworks with permanent porosity. In contrast, the design and synthesis, based on flexible ligands, are more difficult and erratic due to their greater number of degrees of freedom, thus leading to distinct symmetries during the self-assembly process. In recent times, the flexible linkers are often used to build fascinating structures owing to impacting their functionalities to the coordination networks. In fact, the flexible coordination polymers (FCPs) have enormous potential in changing their topologies during the adsorption–desorption or hydrated-dehydrated processes. Moreover, the flexibility of the ligand may incorporate the “breathing” phenomenon which is a reversible flexing of the framework as a function of adsorbed guest. Costantino and co-workers utilized flexible linkers in the first iso-reticular synthesis of three phosphonate based Cu-MOFs, that show a breathing effect upon hydration and dehydration; the mechanism of breathing was mainly attributed to the rotation of linkers. In contrast, when flexible linkers were replaced by more rigid linkers, a different behavior was observed. Thus, the interplay between rigidity and flexibility of the linkers may have various inferences on the resulting framework. A qualitative comparison between the flexibility and rigidity associated in the organic building blocks to enhance the design strategies is an intensified research domain. We are actively engaged in this area last several years and have established some conceptual ideologies in construction of MOFs/CPs from flexible linkers.

elements.content: The present study deals with flexible as well as rigid linkers. We have chosen rigid 1,3-adamantanedicarboxylic acid (H2ADC) and its analogous flexible linker 1,3-adamantanediacetic acid (H2ADA) as multidentate carboxylate ligands to obtain new framework containing compounds. The nonplanar unusual skeleton of adamantane makes them divergent from regular dicarboxylic acid ligands and moreover, the presence of two carboxylate groups in both the ligands offer opportunity of different degree of deprotonation depending on the pH of the reaction mixture and the various number of coordination modes. On the other hand, the bis-imidazole ligands have widely been used to build the fascinating structures because of their excellent coordination ability and variable conformations. In literature, the N-containing auxiliary ligands were interspersed with carboxylate linkers to tune the dimensionality of the framework which often leads to versatile topology with interesting properties. Therefore, in this article, we have studied the mixed-ligand assembly reactions of the flexible/rigid bis-imidazole linker bpbix and bpim and the above-mentioned two adamantane acid ligands H2ADC and H2ADA with Co(II) salt. It is well-known that Co(II) has attracted extensive interest for construction of extended coordination polymer containing compounds, as it can behave as a versatile metal center by adopting diverse coordination geometries. There are, so far, only few examples related to the metal–organic frameworks based on the adamantane acid ligands. Hence, for a systematic investigation, we have varied the flexible and rigid parameters in the organic building blocks and four new coordination polymer containing compounds, formulated as {Co(ADA)(bpbix)} n ·nH2O (1), {Co(ADC)(bpbix)} n (2), {Co(ADA)(bpim)} n ·nH2O (3), and {Co2(ADC)2(bpim)} n (4) have been reported here including their syntheses and structural characterizations by the single crystal X-ray diffraction. We have also studied the temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements for the title compounds. The structural diversity of these four compounds has been discussed in details emphasizing various conformations and connectivity patterns of the ligands.

elements.content: All the chemicals were received as reagent grade and used without any further purification. The ligand bpim was prepared according to the literature procedure. Elemental analyses were determined by FLASH EA series 1112 CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra of solid samples were obtained as KBr pellets on a JASCO-5300 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer using graphite monochromated CuKα1 (1.5406 Å) and Kα2 (1.54439 Å) radiations. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STA 409 PC analyzer and corresponding masses were analyzed by QMS 403 C mass analyzer. Magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Quantum Design VSM-SQUID. The electronic absorption spectra have been recorded on a Cary 100 Bio UV–visible spectrophotometer at room temperature. All the compounds were synthesized (Scheme ) in 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessels (Thermocon, India).
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

All the chemicals were received as reagent grade and used without any further purification. The ligand bpim was prepared according to the literature procedure. Elemental analyses were determined by FLASH EA series 1112 CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra of solid samples were obtained as KBr pellets on a JASCO-5300 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer using graphite monochromated CuKα1 (1.5406 Å) and Kα2 (1.54439 Å) radiations. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STA 409 PC analyzer and corresponding masses were analyzed by QMS 403 C mass analyzer. Magnetic susceptibilities were measured on a Quantum Design VSM-SQUID. The electronic absorption spectra have been recorded on a Cary 100 Bio UV-visible spectrophotometer at room temperature. All the compounds were synthesized (Scheme ) in 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessels (Thermocon, India).

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Protocol of Compounds 1-4 Presented in the Study

elements.content: In the literarture, bpbix molecule was synthesized using n-butyl lithium as a base; herein we have modified the synthetic procedure by using the base NaH as shown in Scheme . bpbix was synthesized by taking sodium hydride (1.9 g, 79.1 mmol) in 10.0 mL of dry THF. Subsequently, imidazole (2.99g, 44.0 mmol), dissolved in 10.0 mL of THF, was added dropwise to NaH solution very slowly with stirring. The stirring was then continued under N2 atmosphere for 30 min. To this solution, 4,4′-bis(chloromethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl (5.02 g, 20.0 mmol) in 20.0 mL of THF was added dropwise and the resulting reaction mixture was heated at refluxing temperature for 8 h. After it was cooled down to room temperature, the solution was poured into 200.0 mL of ice cooled water and then extracted with 3 × 100.0 mL of DCM. Subsequently the DCM extract was dried with Na2SO4, followed by removal of solvent, affording the ligand bpbix in 48% yield. IR (cm–1): 3897 (w), 3743 (m), 2982 (w), 1716 (s), 1645 (m), 1608 (s), 1539 (m), 1510 (s), 1462 (m), 1369 (m), 1314 (s), 1275 (s), 1218 (s), 1168 (s),1105 (m), 1025 (s), 849 (w), 767 (m); mp 165–168 °C; 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): 7.59 (2H, s), 7.55 (4H, d), 7.25 (4H, d), 7.12 (2H, d), 6.95 (2H, d), 5.17 (4H, s). LCMS calcd for C20H18N4, 314; found, 315 [M + H]+.

Subsequently, imidazole (2.99g, 44.0 mmol), dissolved in 10.0 mL of THF, was added dropwise to NaH solution very slowly with stirring. The stirring was then continued under N2 atmosphere for 30 min. To this solution, 4,4'-bis(chloromethyl)-1,1'-biphenyl (5.02 g, 20.0 mmol) in 20.0 mL of THF was added dropwise and the resulting reaction mixture was heated at refluxing temperature for 8 h. After it was cooled down to room temperature, the solution was poured into 200.0 mL of ice cooled water and then extracted with 3 × 100.0 mL of DCM. Subsequently the DCM extract was dried with Na2SO4, followed by removal of solvent, affording the ligand bpbix in 48% yield. elements.clean_text: 2  Synthetic Route Employed for Preparation of bpbix Ligand

elements.content: A mixture of CoCl2.6H2O (59.4 mg, 0.25 mmol), bpbix (78.5 mg, 0.25 mmol) and H2ADA (56.0 mg, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water and stirred for 30 min. The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 5.86 by adding 2 N NaOH solution. Then the reaction mixture was transferred to a 23 mL stainless steel Teflon lined autoclave and sealed followed by heating at 160 °C for 3 days. The resulted blue crystals were collected by filtration and characterized. Yield: 65% (based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C34H38CoN4O5 (M r = 641.61): C, 63.62%; H, 5.97%; N, 8.73%. Found: C, 63.59%; H, 5.81%; N, 8.39%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3419, 3128, 2893, 2838, 1578, 1550, 1446, 1397, 1227, 1101, 1084, 953, 805, 750, 663.

elements.content: Single-crystals suitable for structural determination of all the compounds 1–4 were mounted on a three circle Bruker SMARTAPEX CCD area detector system under Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) graphite monochromated X-ray beam with crystal-to-detector distance of 60 mm, and a collimator of 0.5 mm width. The scans were recorded with a ω scan width of 0.3°. Data reduction was performed by SAINTPLUS; empirical absorption corrections using equivalent reflections were performed by program SADABS. Structure solutions were done using SHELXS-97 and full-matrix least-squares refinement was carried out using SHELXL-97 for all four compounds. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms on the C atoms were introduced on calculated positions and were included in the refinement riding on their respective parent atoms. Attempts to locate all the hydrogen atoms for the solvent water molecules in the crystal structure of compound 1 and 3 through Fourier electron density map were failed. However, no attempts were made to fix these atoms on their parent atoms. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1–4 are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in section 5 of file. Topological analyses of the compounds were performed by using the TOPOS software. CCDC-1035737, CCDC-1035738, CCDC-1035739, and CCDC-1035740 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for compounds 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. Relevant crystal data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.atc.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223–336–033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Structure Determination of the Compounds 1-4 

Single-crystals suitable for structural determination of all the compounds 1-4 were mounted on a three circle Bruker SMARTAPEX CCD area detector system under Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) graphite monochromated X-ray beam with crystal-to-detector distance of 60 mm, and a collimator of 0.5 mm width. The scans were recorded with a ω scan width of 0.3°. Data reduction was performed by SAINTPLUS; empirical absorption corrections using equivalent reflections were performed by program SADABS. Structure solutions were done using SHELXS-97 and full-matrix least-squares refinement was carried out using SHELXL-97 for all four compounds. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms on the C atoms were introduced on calculated positions and were included in the refinement riding on their respective parent atoms. Attempts to locate all the hydrogen atoms for the solvent water molecules in the crystal structure of compound 1 and 3 through Fourier electron density map were failed. However, no attempts were made to fix these atoms on their parent atoms. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1-4 are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in section 5 of  file. Topological analyses of the compounds were performed by using the TOPOS software. CCDC-1035737, CCDC-1035738, CCDC-1035739, and CCDC-1035740 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for compounds 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. Relevant crystal data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.atc.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

Compounds 1–4 were synthesized by solvothermal/hydrothermal technique. We have taken the CoCl2.6H2O as the source of the Co(II) metal ion. We employed the flexible and rigid analogues of both the adamantane dipodal acid ligands (H2ADA and H2ADC) and the bis-imidazole ligands (bpbix and bpim) by interexchanging among them in the reaction system. The heating temperature of the reaction mixture was optimized for compound 1, 3, and 4 at 160 °C for 3 days; whereas the single crystal of the compound 2 were obtained in good yield at 130 °C for 4 days. Before heating, the initial pH of the reaction mixture was increased by adding 2 N NaOH solution as mentioned in the synthesis part, but, we failed to get the compound 3 at higher pH, which is formed at the initial pH (without adding any NaOH) of the reaction mixture. It has been observed that, the initial pH of the reaction mixture of compounds 1 and 4 are 4.06 and 4.25 respectively, whereas in case of compound 2 the initial pH was 3.44. In order to deprotonate the −COOH group of the adamantane acid ligand, the initial pHs of the reaction mixtures were increased. For compounds 1 and 4, the final pH of reaction mixtures was maintained above 5.50 and for compound 2, the pH was increased from 3.44 to 4.32. All the reactions were carried out in water medium except the compound 4, which has been formed only in assorted solvent mixture (water/methanol/DMF = 4:3:3).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Compounds 1-4 were synthesized by solvothermal/hydrothermal technique. We have taken the CoCl2.6H2O as the source of the Co(II) metal ion. We employed the flexible and rigid analogues of both the adamantane dipodal acid ligands (H2ADA and H2ADC) and the bis-imidazole ligands (bpbix and bpim) by interexchanging among them in the reaction system. The heating temperature of the reaction mixture was optimized for compound 1, 3, and 4 at 160 °C for 3 days; whereas the single crystal of the compound 2 were obtained in good yield at 130 °C for 4 days. Before heating, the initial pH of the reaction mixture was increased by adding 2 N NaOH solution as mentioned in the synthesis part, but, we failed to get the compound 3 at higher pH, which is formed at the initial pH (without adding any NaOH) of the reaction mixture. It has been observed that, the initial pH of the reaction mixture of compounds 1 and 4 are 4.06 and 4.25 respectively, whereas in case of compound 2 the initial pH was 3.44. In order to deprotonate the -COOH group of the adamantane acid ligand, the initial pHs of the reaction mixtures were increased. For compounds 1 and 4, the final pH of reaction mixtures was maintained above 5.50 and for compound 2, the pH was increased from 3.44 to 4.32. All the reactions were carried out in water medium except the compound 4, which has been formed only in assorted solvent mixture (water/methanol/DMF = 4:3:3).

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P-1. As shown in Figure a, the molecular structure consists of one Co(II) center, two ADA2– ligands, two bpbix ligands and one uncoordinated water molecule. The coordination geometry around Co(II) center is tetrahedral with the distortion parameter τ4 (0.94), calculated by the four-coordinate geometry index (τ4 = {360° – (α + β)}/141, where α and β are the two largest angles of the tetrahedron), in which the metal center is coordinated by two oxygen atoms of two ADA2– linkers and two N atoms from two bpbix linkers (Co–O and Co–N distances are in the range of 1.956–2.019 Å). In the crystal structure of compound 1, the acetate side chains in the ADA2– ligand adopt a gauche conformation with a torsion angle of 97.02° (viewed through C21–C22–C33-C34) with simple monodentate coordination mode (μ1-η1: η0). The connectivity of ADA2– with Co(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 1D chain along crystallographic a axis creating a Co···Co separation of 9.912 Å. In these Co(II)–ADA2– chains, the adamantane rings are located on the same side of the axis and all the Co(II) centers are arranged in a linear fashion along the axis. In the adjacent 1D chains, the adamantane rings are arranged in an opposite manner, that is, in one chain, the successive Co(II) centers are connected by ADA2– in U fashion and in the next adjacent chain, the consecutive Co(II) centers are connected in a inverted U fashion as shown in Figure b. Furthermore, the Co(II) centers of these Co(II)–ADA2– chains are interconnected by the bpbix ligand, affording the formation of an undulating 2D layer. The bpbix ligand adopts a perfect trans conformation with 180° torsion angle between two imidazole rings; two phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer are not twisted with respect to each other and confined to the same plane. But, in the above-described 2D sheet, the bpbix linker has tied the adjacent Co(II)–ADA2– chains at two different distances: one set of bpbix linkers joins the chains by connecting the Co(II) centers with a separation of 16.38 Å, in which the twisting angle of imidazole rings from the mean plane of the biphenyl is 74.06° and the other set of bpbix linkers connect the Co(II) centers at 16.38 Å distances, where the imidazole rings are twisted by an angle of 75.39°. This remarkable connectivity results in the formation of a rippling 2D sheet rather than a planar sheet and thereby results in the formation of two different grid sizes with dimensions 19.708 × 18.578 and 23.191 × 18.628 Å2, respectively (Figure c). By considering the Co(II) centers as 4-connected nodes and the ADA2– and bpbix ligand as linear linkers, the resulting structure can be described as a uninodal 4-connected net with schalfi point symbol {44, 62}, more often known as sql topological type. Moreover, the lattice water molecules and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms, present in the framework, extend the network through the hydrogen bonding interactions. Interestingly, in the crystal structure, the adjacent layers are interpenetrated to each other affording a 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration, which creates an unusual 2-fold interpenetrated sql network (Figure d). This interpenetrating framework is further strengthened mostly by the hydrogen bonding interactions between the adjacent layers.

Description of Crystal Structures

{Co(ADA)(bpbix)} n ⋅nH2O (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P-1. As shown in Figure a, the molecular structure consists of one Co(II) center, two ADA2- ligands, two bpbix ligands and one uncoordinated water molecule. The coordination geometry around Co(II) center is tetrahedral with the distortion parameter τ4 (0.94), calculated by the four-coordinate geometry index (τ4 = {360° - (α + β)}/141, where α and β are the two largest angles of the tetrahedron), in which the metal center is coordinated by two oxygen atoms of two ADA2- linkers and two N atoms from two bpbix linkers (Co-O and Co-N distances are in the range of 1.956-2.019 Å). In the crystal structure of compound 1, the acetate side chains in the ADA2- ligand adopt a gauche conformation with a torsion angle of 97.02° (viewed through C21-C22-C33-C34) with simple monodentate coordination mode (μ1-η1: η0). The connectivity of ADA2- with Co(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 1D chain along crystallographic a axis creating a Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation of 9.912 Å. In these Co(II)-ADA2- chains, the adamantane rings are located on the same side of the axis and all the Co(II) centers are arranged in a linear fashion along the axis. In the adjacent 1D chains, the adamantane rings are arranged in an opposite manner, that is, in one chain, the successive Co(II) centers are connected by ADA2- in U fashion and in the next adjacent chain, the consecutive Co(II) centers are connected in a inverted U fashion as shown in Figure b. Furthermore, the Co(II) centers of these Co(II)-ADA2- chains are interconnected by the bpbix ligand, affording the formation of an undulating 2D layer. The bpbix ligand adopts a perfect trans conformation with 180° torsion angle between two imidazole rings; two phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer are not twisted with respect to each other and confined to the same plane. But, in the above-described 2D sheet, the bpbix linker has tied the adjacent Co(II)-ADA2- chains at two different distances: one set of bpbix linkers joins the chains by connecting the Co(II) centers with a separation of 16.38 Å, in which the twisting angle of imidazole rings from the mean plane of the biphenyl is 74.06° and the other set of bpbix linkers connect the Co(II) centers at 16.38 Å distances, where the imidazole rings are twisted by an angle of 75.39°. This remarkable connectivity results in the formation of a rippling 2D sheet rather than a planar sheet and thereby results in the formation of two different grid sizes with dimensions 19.708 × 18.578 and 23.191 × 18.628 Å2, respectively (Figure c). By considering the Co(II) centers as 4-connected nodes and the ADA2- and bpbix ligand as linear linkers, the resulting structure can be described as a uninodal 4-connected net with schalfi point symbol {44, 62}, more often known as sql topological type. Moreover, the lattice water molecules and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms, present in the framework, extend the network through the hydrogen bonding interactions. Interestingly, in the crystal structure, the adjacent layers are interpenetrated to each other affording a 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration, which creates an unusual 2-fold interpenetrated sql network (Figure d). This interpenetrating framework is further strengthened mostly by the hydrogen bonding interactions between the adjacent layers.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction crystallography reveals that the compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c. As illustrated in Figure a, the crystallographically independent CoII center, which has distorted tetrahedral geometry with distortion parameter τ4 (0.88), is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from the two different ADC2– linkers and two nitrogen atoms of imidazole rings from the two different bpbix ligands. The bond lengths surrounding the Co(II) center (i.e., Co–O and Co–N bond distances) are in the range of 1.941–2.033 Å and the bond angles are in range of 105.2–119.9°. The doubly deprotonated ADC2– ligand connects adjacent two CoII ions in a bidentate fashion through carboxylate groups in a μ1-η1: η0 coordination mode. This connectivity leads to the formation of 1D chain with a separation of 9.712 Å between two CoII centers. Unlike the situation, observed in the crystal structure of compound 1, in these Co(II)-ADC2– chains (compound 2), the adjacent adamantane rings are located alternatively on both sides of the chain in a semi zigzag fashion and the consecutive three CoII centers are arranged in a angular manner (Figure b) rather than a linear fashion. These zigzag 1D chains are connected by the secondary linker bpbix through N atoms from the two imidazole rings at the CoII center, thereby completing its tetrahedral geometry. Unlike the crystal structure in compound 1, the imidazole rings in the long secondary linker bpbix (in the crystal structure of compound 2) adopts a guache conformation, closely to cis configuration, with respect to each other with an synclinal torsion angle of 58.68° (viewed through N4–C20–C4–N2); in addition to this conformation, the phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer are twisted with respect to each other by an angle of 28.60°. These two features of bpbix linker of compound 2, facilitate this ligand to coordinate the CoII centers between the adjacent CoII-ADC2– chains by creating a separation of 15.61 Å between two cobalt centers. The two changeable geometrical restraints, that is, flexibility becuase of CH2 groups and twisting of phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer, modulate the bpbix ligand itself to meet the coordination requirements imposed by the connectivity of ADC2– linker. In other words, these two 1D chains, namely, CoII–ADC2– and CoII–bpbix, join/meet together at common CoII centers resulting in the formation of 2D nets of sql type with a dimension of 15.61 × 9.719 Å2 (Figure c). Even though, these 2D sheets are 4-connected, they are neither corrugated nor planar; but they form an interesting layered topology. The 2D sheets are stacked over each other, whereby the adjacent sheets are in staggered and alternate sheets are eclipsed; simply it can be expressed as ABABAB packing pattern (Figure d).

elements.content: We have used an analogous rigid imidazole ligand (bpim) along with adamantane diacetic acid (H2ADA) to obtain the compound 3, which is red in color. The compound has crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) metal ion, one deprotonated ADA2–, one bpim ligand and one lattice water molecule (Figure a). The tetrahedral geometry around the Co(II) metal ion is characterized by the distortion parameter τ4 (0.86) indicating that it is slight more distorted compared to the τ4 value, determined for compound 1. The coordination sphere around the Co(II) metal ion is ccomposed by two oxygen atoms having the Co–O bond distances 1.984 and 2.034 Å and the nitrogen atoms having Co–N bond distances 2.039 and 2.042 Å. Each ADA2– ligand connects two Co(II) metal ion with its each carboxylate group in a monodentate mode, with a Co···Co separation of 11.25 Å. This connectivity results in the formation of metal-acid 1D chain, where acetate group in ADA2– linker has trans conformation with a torsion angle of 119.74° to connect the Co(II) ions in an angular manner. These Co(II) atoms are further connected by the imidazole N atoms of the bpimp linker along the crystallographically b axis creating a separation of 17.625 Å. Both the phenyl rings in the bpim linker are not tilted with respect to each other, which imparts planarity to the linker; in a similar way, imidazole rings also exist in the plane of the biphenyl ring. The interconnectivity of the Co–ADA2– chain and the Co–bpim chain leads to a 2D sql nets (Figure b). In this 2D sheet, along the crystallographic c axis (Co–ADA2– chain), the angle between the adjacent three Co(II) atom is 153.55° and along the crystallographic b axis (Co–bpim chain), this angle is 76.39°. The nonplanar arrangement of the Co(II) metal ions in the 2D sheet, leads to a wavy network having two different types of parallelograms. One type of parallelogram consists of dimensions of 21.94 × 19.83 Å2 with angles of 83.62° and 96.38°, whereas, another one is of 16.76 × 24.36 Å2 with angles of 113.20° and 66.79°. Further, the adjacent sheets are arranged with the grids of each layer in a noninterpenetrated parallel manner (Figure c). The lattice water molecules, present in the 2D layer, take part in strong hydrogen bonding interactions. Each water molecule is a part of one intralayer H-bonding interactions, where the water molecule has interacted (within the layer) through the O5···O4 hydrogen bonding interaction with the uncoordinated oxygen atom of the carboxylate group of the ADA2– ligand (green in color in Figure d). There is one interlayer H-bonding interaction through O5···O3 involving coordinated oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group of the adjacent layer (pink in color in Figure d). These two types of H-bonding interactions, namely, intralayer and interlayer interactions, that involve the lattice water molecule and the carboxylate group, lead to a 1D chain of water-carboxylate [···O(w)···OUC–C–OC···O(w)···], which has sewed the adjacent 2D sheet to a final 3D supramolecular framework (Figure e).

These Co(II) atoms are further connected by the imidazole N atoms of the bpimp linker along the crystallographically b axis creating a separation of 17.625 Å. Both the phenyl rings in the bpim linker are not tilted with respect to each other, which imparts planarity to the linker; in a similar way, imidazole rings also exist in the plane of the biphenyl ring. The interconnectivity of the Co-ADA2- chain and the Co-bpim chain leads to a 2D sql nets  (Figure b). In this 2D sheet, along the crystallographic c axis (Co-ADA2- chain), the angle between the adjacent three Co(II) atom is 153.55° and along the crystallographic b axis (Co-bpim chain), this angle is 76.39°. The nonplanar arrangement of the Co(II) metal ions in the 2D sheet, leads to a wavy network having two different types of parallelograms. One type of parallelogram consists of dimensions of 21.94 × 19.83 Å2 with angles of 83.62° and 96.38°, whereas, another one is of 16.76 × 24.36 Å2 with angles of 113.20° and 66.79°. Further, the adjacent sheets are arranged with the grids of each layer in a noninterpenetrated parallel manner (Figure c). The lattice water molecules, present in the 2D layer, take part in strong hydrogen bonding interactions. Each water molecule is a part of one intralayer H-bonding interactions, where the water molecule has interacted (within the layer) through the O5⋅⋅⋅O4 hydrogen bonding interaction with the uncoordinated oxygen atom of the carboxylate group of the ADA2- ligand (green in color in Figure d). There is one interlayer H-bonding interaction through O5⋅⋅⋅O3 involving coordinated oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group of the adjacent layer (pink in color in Figure d). These two types of H-bonding interactions, namely, intralayer and interlayer interactions, that involve the lattice water molecule and the carboxylate group, lead to a 1D chain of water-carboxylate [⋅⋅⋅O(w)⋅⋅⋅OUC-C-OC⋅⋅⋅O(w)⋅⋅⋅], which has sewed the adjacent 2D sheet to a final 3D supramolecular framework (Figure e).

elements.content: The result of the crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 4 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit (Figure a) in the crystal structure of compound 4 consists of two crystallographically independent Co(II) metal ions, two ADC2– ligands and one bpim ligand. Both the Co(II) metal ions are coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three different ADC2– ligands and one nitrogen atom from one bpim ligand affording a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the metal ions. The Co–O bond lengths around the Co1 atom are in the range of 1.983–2.380 Å and around Co2 metal ion are in the range of 1.998–2.258 Å, whereas, the Co–N bond lengths are 2.068, 2.048 Å for Co1 and Co2 respectively. The distortion parameter τ5, for Co1 and Co2 are 1.04 and 0.92 respectively, calculated by the five-coordinate geometry index τ5 = (β – α) /60, [τ5 = 1 for a trigonal bipyramidal structure, where, τ5 = 0 for a square pyramidal structure], where α and β are the two largest angles in the five-coordinate complex to give an index of the degree of trigonality. In the crystal of compound 4, each ADC2– ligand adopts a tetradentate coordination mode in which one carboxylate group acts as a chelating bidentate (μ1-η1: η1) donor and the other as a bridging bidentate (μ2-η1: η1) donor. The chelating bidentate mode of the carboxylate group assists the formation of two different Co2 dimers as SBUs, namely,{(Co1)2(COO)2} and {(Co2)2(COO)2}. The {(Co1)2(COO)2} dimer adopts almost a planar conformation because of syn-syn coordination mode of the carboxylate group with the Co1 metal ions with Co1–O–C–O torsion angle of 19.11° and 6.33°. On the other hand, the carboxylate group in {(Co2)2(COO)2} dimer adopts a highly nonplanar syn-skew coordination mode with the Co2 metal ions, that deviate much from the carboxylate plane affording the spiral conformation of the {(Co2)2(COO)2} moiety with the Co2–O–C–O torsion angle 1.46° and 94.46° (Figure b). In these metal-carboxylate dimers, the Co2···Co2 distance (3.469 Å) is larger than the Co1···Co1 separation (3.185 Å). As shown in Figure c, two dimers are connected by a pair of ADC2– ligands through the bridging bidentate modes of the carboxylate group to form a 1D double chain, where {(Co1)2(COO)2}and {(Co2)2(COO)2} dimers are arranged in an alternate way with the separation of 8.962 Å between the two dimer units. Further, the double chains are pillared by bpim ligand to generate 2D sheets (Figure d). The two phenyl rings of the bpim ligand are not in the same plane in contrast to that in compound 3 and twisted to each other by a dihedral angle of 32.68°. Apart from this, one imidazole ring is also tilted from the plane of the adjacent phenyl ring by a dihedral angle 42.12°, whereas, the another imidazole ring remains almost in the same plane (dihedral angle 3.48°) with the adjacent phenyl ring. The N atom of the one imidazole ring of the bpim ligand coordinates to the metal ion of the {(Co1)2(COO)2} dimer of one metal-acid double chain, whereas, the N atom of other imidazole ring coordinates to the other {(Co2)2(COO)2} dimer of another double chain. The separation between the {(Co1)2(COO)2} dimer and {(Co2)2(COO)2} dimer created by the bpim ligand is 17.33 Å. If we consider each metal dimer as single node and connect them by simplified representation of ADC2– and bpim ligands, it results in 2D sheets of sql type topology.

elements.content: A systematic correlation between the linkers employed and the final architectures reveals deep insights in the self-assembly process. The coordination control of the architectures has been studied in depth to highlight rigidity and flexibility associated with the linkers. All the compounds, described in this article, are synthesized using duel linkers and these dual linkers in each of the title compounds are chosen as follows: (flexible, flexible) for compound 1, (rigid, flexible) for compound 2, (flexible, rigid) for compound 3 and finally (rigid, rigid) for compound 4. Interestingly, all the compounds have 2D sheet-like extended structures in their crystals with the Co(II) center in tetrahedral coordination sphere. But, the differences in their final architectures can be explained by considering the rigidity and flexibility of the used linkers as follows. The skeleton of adamantane is unique in the sense that it is a rigid, nonplanar and virtually stress-free molecule. The attachment of coordination groups to this nonplanar skeleton would always result in the formation of interesting coordination connectivities. In this work, we have chosen two adamantane-based linkers, namely H2ADC and H2ADA with carboxylic and acetate groups respectively to the skeleton of the adamantane at 1,3 positions. Both the linkers show unusual coordination modes with CoII centers in the resulting compounds, which can be rationalized by exploring the flexibility in H2ADA linker and rigidity in case of H2ADC linker along with already existed nonplanarity in the skeleton under following headings i–iii.
elements.clean_text:
Assessing the Influential Role of Rigidity versus Flexibility in the Self-Assembly Process in a Perceptive Approach

A systematic correlation between the linkers employed and the final architectures reveals deep insights in the self-assembly process. The coordination control of the architectures has been studied in depth to highlight rigidity and flexibility associated with the linkers. All the compounds, described in this article, are synthesized using duel linkers and these dual linkers in each of the title compounds are chosen as follows: (flexible, flexible) for compound 1, (rigid, flexible) for compound 2, (flexible, rigid) for compound 3 and finally (rigid, rigid) for compound 4. Interestingly, all the compounds have 2D sheet-like extended structures in their crystals with the Co(II) center in tetrahedral coordination sphere. But, the differences in their final architectures can be explained by considering the rigidity and flexibility of the used linkers as follows. The skeleton of adamantane is unique in the sense that it is a rigid, nonplanar and virtually stress-free molecule. The attachment of coordination groups to this nonplanar skeleton would always result in the formation of interesting coordination connectivities. In this work, we have chosen two adamantane-based linkers, namely H2ADC and H2ADA with carboxylic and acetate groups respectively to the skeleton of the adamantane at 1,3 positions. Both the linkers show unusual coordination modes with CoII centers in the resulting compounds, which can be rationalized by exploring the flexibility in H2ADA linker and rigidity in case of H2ADC linker along with already existed nonplanarity in the skeleton under following headings i-iii.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , Co(II)–acid forms four different patterns of chains in the four compounds 1–4, respectively, and these patterns are the blueprints of the respective final architectures. In case of compound 1, the flexible ADA2– linker connects the CoII centers in an interesting fashion, where all the Co(II) centers are arranged in a linear fashion rather than in a wavy mode, which is rare in terms of the geometrical constraints imposed by the geometry of adamantane moiety. Also in case of compound 1, the CoII–ADA2– chains in the layer are arranged peculiarly: two adjacent successive chains are arranged nonlinearly in a corrugated fashion as shown in Figure b. Whereas, in the crystal structure of compound 2, the rigid ADC2– ligand adopts a nonlinear connectivity with CoII centers to form a 1D helical-type chain leaving the vacant coordination strand. Also in 2, the CoII–ADC2– chains are arranged one after the other along the layer linearly in an eclipsed manner. The similar pattern of metal-acid chain has been observed in case of compound 3 also, in which the Co–ADA2– also favors the 1D zigzag chain by arranging the Co(II) centers along the chain in a noncollinear fashion. In general the twisted geometry of adamantane generates 1D zigzag chains due to its helical coordination tendency which is observed in case of compounds 2 and 3. In case of compound 4, the rigid ADC2– forms a 1D double-strand type chain, the formation of which can be explained by the twisted geometry of ADC2– that can form 1D zigzag chain by creating a vacant strand, which can subsequently be filled by another such 1D zigzag chain of ADC2– resulting in a double-strand chain with Co-dimers as nodes. In a nutshell, the coordination connectivity of the flexible ADA2– has been changed from linear chain in compound 1 to zigzag connectivity in compound 3 and the rigid ADC2– has been changed from zigzag connectivity in 2 to a double-strand chain in compound 4. When these 1D chains are interconnected by the secondary linkers, the characteristic geometrical imprints of the chains are transmitted though out the structure in all cases.
elements.clean_text:
Geometrical constraints induced by the adamantane building block in formation of Co(II)-Acid chains

As shown in Figure , Co(II)-acid forms four different patterns of chains in the four compounds 1-4, respectively, and these patterns are the blueprints of the respective final architectures. In case of compound 1, the flexible ADA2- linker connects the CoII centers in an interesting fashion, where all the Co(II) centers are arranged in a linear fashion rather than in a wavy mode, which is rare in terms of the geometrical constraints imposed by the geometry of adamantane moiety. Also in case of compound 1, the CoII-ADA2- chains in the layer are arranged peculiarly: two adjacent successive chains are arranged nonlinearly in a corrugated fashion as shown in Figure b. Whereas, in the crystal structure of compound 2, the rigid ADC2- ligand adopts a nonlinear connectivity with CoII centers to form a 1D helical-type chain leaving the vacant coordination strand. Also in 2, the CoII-ADC2- chains are arranged one after the other along the layer linearly in an eclipsed manner. The similar pattern of metal-acid chain has been observed in case of compound 3 also, in which the Co-ADA2- also favors the 1D zigzag chain by arranging the Co(II) centers along the chain in a noncollinear fashion. In general the twisted geometry of adamantane generates 1D zigzag chains due to its helical coordination tendency which is observed in case of compounds 2 and 3. In case of compound 4, the rigid ADC2- forms a 1D double-strand type chain, the formation of which can be explained by the twisted geometry of ADC2- that can form 1D zigzag chain by creating a vacant strand, which can subsequently be filled by another such 1D zigzag chain of ADC2- resulting in a double-strand chain with Co-dimers as nodes. In a nutshell, the coordination connectivity of the flexible ADA2- has been changed from linear chain in compound 1 to zigzag connectivity in compound 3 and the rigid ADC2- has been changed from zigzag connectivity in 2 to a double-strand chain in compound 4. When these 1D chains are interconnected by the secondary linkers, the characteristic geometrical imprints of the chains are transmitted though out the structure in all cases.

elements.content: The metal-acid chains in compounds 1 and 2 are linked by the flexible secondary N-donor linker 1,4-bix and in compounds 3 and 4, they are linked by the rigid secondary linker 1,4-bpim. In case of 1, the linearly arranged Co(II) atoms in the Co(II)-ADA2– chain do not enforce any restraints to the secondary linker; therefore, the phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer do not twist with respect to each other and confined to a same plane, also it exists in its usual trans conformation (Figure a and c). The CoII centers of the metal–acid chains in 2 are non-linearly arranged. As a result, the phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer of secondary linker are twisted with respect to each other to an extent of 28.6° to modulate its conformation to meet the coordination requirements, imposed by the ADC2– connectivity; 1,4-bpbix linker, in this compound, exists in a typical guache conformation. But the major difference of connectivity of 1D chains observed in case of 1 and 2 is due to arrangement of CoII-ADA2– chains along the layer in ∪ and ∩ manners alternatively in compound 1; thus the associated bpbix linkers adopt two different types of connective patterns (which differs in the twisting of imidazole rings from the mean biphenyl plane) to connect the adjacent metal acid chains. But in compound 2, as the arrangement of CoII–ADC2– chains have identical patterns along the layer, the associated bpbix linkers adopt only one particular type of connectivity. Even though, the CoII centers in the metal-acid chains in compound 3 are non linearly arranged, the phenyl rings in the secondary linker 1,4-bpim do not twist with respect to each other and adopt a planar configuration. In compound 4, two types of Co-dimers, which differs in the configuration, are arranged in the metal–acid chain resulting in the formation of asymmetric chain; in this case a twisting in the phenyl rings of the biphenyl spacer (32.68°) in the imidazole ligand is observed. This twisting mainly arises due to connectivity of 1,4-bpim linker with two metal centers from different types of dimers (compound 4). A close inspection of four structures reveals that, as the degree of rigidity increases in the linkers, the structures tend to change their architectures according to the geometry of the linkers. With both the flexible linkers in compound 1, an interpenetrated structure has been found to be formed. With (rigid, flexible) dual linkers in 2 and (flexible, rigid) dual linkers in 3, similar type of 2D corrugated sheets have been observed in compounds 2 and 3. And finally, with both rigid linkers in compound 4, it forms a planar 2D sheet.
elements.clean_text:
Connectivity Patterns Adopted by the Secondary Linkers

The metal-acid chains in compounds 1 and 2 are linked by the flexible secondary N-donor linker 1,4-bix and in compounds 3 and 4, they are linked by the rigid secondary linker 1,4-bpim. In case of 1, the linearly arranged Co(II) atoms in the Co(II)-ADA2- chain do not enforce any restraints to the secondary linker; therefore, the phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer do not twist with respect to each other and confined to a same plane, also it exists in its usual trans conformation (Figure a and c). The CoII centers of the metal-acid chains in 2 are non-linearly arranged. As a result, the phenyl rings in the biphenyl spacer of secondary linker are twisted with respect to each other to an extent of 28.6° to modulate its conformation to meet the coordination requirements, imposed by the ADC2- connectivity; 1,4-bpbix linker, in this compound, exists in a typical guache conformation. But the major difference of connectivity of 1D chains observed in case of 1 and 2 is due to arrangement of CoII-ADA2- chains along the layer in ∪ and ∩ manners alternatively in compound 1; thus the associated bpbix linkers adopt two different types of connective patterns (which differs in the twisting of imidazole rings from the mean biphenyl plane) to connect the adjacent metal acid chains. But in compound 2, as the arrangement of CoII-ADC2- chains have identical patterns along the layer, the associated bpbix linkers adopt only one particular type of connectivity. Even though, the CoII centers in the metal-acid chains in compound 3 are non linearly arranged, the phenyl rings in the secondary linker 1,4-bpim do not twist with respect to each other and adopt a planar configuration. In compound 4, two types of Co-dimers, which differs in the configuration, are arranged in the metal-acid chain resulting in the formation of asymmetric chain; in this case a twisting in the phenyl rings of the biphenyl spacer (32.68°) in the imidazole ligand is observed. This twisting mainly arises due to connectivity of 1,4-bpim linker with two metal centers from different types of dimers (compound 4). A close inspection of four structures reveals that, as the degree of rigidity increases in the linkers, the structures tend to change their architectures according to the geometry of the linkers. With both the flexible linkers in compound 1, an interpenetrated structure has been found to be formed. With (rigid, flexible) dual linkers in 2 and (flexible, rigid) dual linkers in 3, similar type of 2D corrugated sheets have been observed in compounds 2 and 3. And finally, with both rigid linkers in compound 4, it forms a planar 2D sheet.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the stacking patterns of 2D sheets in all the compounds have been studied with the aid of topological representation. In compound 1, the 2D interpenetrated double layers are stacked in same configuration with small sliding angle between two sheets. Whereas, in the crystal structure of compound 2, the successive 2D sheets are stacked in different configurations resembling the pattern of mirror symmetry and also all the layers are collinear. In case of compound 3, all the 2D layers are collinearly stacked with same configuration; this stacking leads to the formation of the 1D channel through the 2D layers. In compound 4, where Co-dimers are present as nodes, the 2D layers are stacked with same configuration; in the adjacent layers, the Co-dimers are translated in such a way leading to the visualization that adjacent layers are not identical and alternate layers are identical. The geometrical constraints, imposed by the linkers, direct the geometry of the 2D layers which unswervingly influences the stacking patterns of the 2D layers. The geometrical constraints, exhibited by the 2D layers in all the compounds are tabulated in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Stacking Pattern of the 2D Coordination Layer

As shown in Figure , the stacking patterns of 2D sheets in all the compounds have been studied with the aid of topological representation. In compound 1, the 2D interpenetrated double layers are stacked in same configuration with small sliding angle between two sheets. Whereas, in the crystal structure of compound 2, the successive 2D sheets are stacked in different configurations resembling the pattern of mirror symmetry and also all the layers are collinear. In case of compound 3, all the 2D layers are collinearly stacked with same configuration; this stacking leads to the formation of the 1D channel through the 2D layers. In compound 4, where Co-dimers are present as nodes, the 2D layers are stacked with same configuration; in the adjacent layers, the Co-dimers are translated in such a way leading to the visualization that adjacent layers are not identical and alternate layers are identical. The geometrical constraints, imposed by the linkers, direct the geometry of the 2D layers which unswervingly influences the stacking patterns of the 2D layers. The geometrical constraints, exhibited by the 2D layers in all the compounds are tabulated in Table .

The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compound 1 under an applied field of 2000 Oe have been plotted as χM versus T and χM T versus T curves (Figure a). The room temperature χM T value of compound 1 is 2.71 cm3 K mol–1, which is much higher than that expected for three isolated S = 3/2 spin centers (1.875 cm3 K mol–1). As the temperature is lowered, the χM T decreases smoothly to 1.75 cm3 K mol–1 at 3.5 K. The temperature dependent nature of the magnetic susceptibility graph and the negative Weiss constant θ (= −10 K) indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of compound 1. The considerable difference between the experimental and expected room temperature χMT values indicates the existence of the spin–orbit coupling in this system. The spin–orbit coupling has been calculated by the expression for S = 3/2 systems, which accounts for spin–orbit coupling with dominant zero field splitting effects, D (eqs –) χ ∥ = ( N g 2 β 2 / k B T ) [ A / B ] where A = [ 1 + 9 ⁡ exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] and B = [ 4 ( 1 + exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] χ ⊥ = ( N g 2 β 2 / k B T ) [ C / D ] where C = [ 4 + ( 3 k B T / D ) ( 1 − exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] D = [ 4 ( 1 + exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] χ M ′ = [ ( χ ∥ + χ ⊥ ) / 3 ] χ M = χ M ′ / { 1 − χ M ′ ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 β 2 ) } where N is Avogadro’s number, β, the Bohr Magneton, k B, Boltzmann’s constant, g, the Lande g value, and D, the zero field splitting. The best fit has been obtained from 2–300 K with g = 1.81(2), D = 2.21(1) cm–1, and zJ′ = 0.5(6) cm–1 with agreement factor of 2.4 × 10–4. As mentioned before, the Co(II) metal ion in compound 1 has distorted tetrahedral geometry. This may be attributed to zero-field splitting (ZFS) of the 4A2 ground state with a positive sign of the D value for compound 1. According to literature for tetrahedral coordination, D values are moderate, up to around 10 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Compound 1 

The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compound 1 under an applied field of 2000 Oe have been plotted as χM versus T and χM T versus T curves (Figure a). The room temperature χM T value of compound 1 is 2.71 cm3 K mol-1, which is much higher than that expected for three isolated S = 3/2 spin centers (1.875 cm3 K mol-1). As the temperature is lowered, the χM T decreases smoothly to 1.75 cm3 K mol-1 at 3.5 K. The temperature dependent nature of the magnetic susceptibility graph and the negative Weiss constant θ (= -10 K) indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of compound 1. The considerable difference between the experimental and expected room temperature χMT values indicates the existence of the spin-orbit coupling in this system. The spin-orbit coupling has been calculated by the expression for S = 3/2 systems, which accounts for spin-orbit coupling with dominant zero field splitting effects, D  (eqs -) 1  χ ∥ =  ( N   g   2     β   2   /   k   B   T )   [ A / B ]   where  A =  [ 1 + 9 ⁡ exp  ( - 2 D /   k   B   T )  ]   and  B = [ 4  ( 1 + exp  ( - 2 D /   k   B   T )  ]     2  χ ⊥ =  ( N   g   2     β   2   /   k   B   T )   [ C / D ]   where  C = [ 4 +  ( 3   k   B   T / D )   ( 1 - exp  ( - 2 D /   k   B   T )  ]      D = [ 4  ( 1 + exp  ( - 2 D /   k   B   T )  ]     3    χ   M  '  =  [  ( χ ∥ + χ ⊥ )  / 3 ]     4    χ   M   =   χ   M  '  /  { 1 -   χ   M  '   ( 2 z J ' / N   g   2     β   2   )  }   where N is Avogadro's number, β, the Bohr Magneton, k B, Boltzmann's constant, g, the Lande g value, and D, the zero field splitting. The best fit has been obtained from 2-300 K with g = 1.81(2), D = 2.21(1) cm-1, and zJ' = 0.5(6) cm-1 with agreement factor of 2.4 × 10-4. As mentioned before, the Co(II) metal ion in compound 1 has distorted tetrahedral geometry. This may be attributed to zero-field splitting (ZFS) of the 4A2 ground state with a positive sign of the D value for compound 1. According to literature for tetrahedral coordination, D values are moderate, up to around 10 cm-1.

Compound 3 

Temperature-dependent magnetic studies for compound 3 were performed at 2000 Oe. As shown in Figure b, the room temperature χM T value of compound 3 is 2.37 cm3 K mol-1, which is higher than the calculated spin-only value for an isolated Co(II) atom (1.875 cm3 K mol-1, S = 3/2); this is attributed to the orbital contribution arising from the distorted tetrahedral Co(II) ion. As the temperature decreases, the χM T value decreases continuously to 1.24 cm3 K mol-1 at 3.5K and 1/χ  M  vs T plot of this compound follows the Curie-Weiss law (see , Figure S2) with a negative Weiss constant θ= -13.10 (1) K. The observation of orbital contribution has been calculated by the eqs - as mentioned for compound 1. The best fit has been obtained with g = 1.9748(2) and D = 5.33(1) cm-1 with agreement factor of 1.82 × 10-4. In case of compound 3, a further increase in the magnitude of the D value was observed; however, there are some examples with even greater values of the D-parameter.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data for a tetrahedral Co(II) ion with S = 3/2 system are unaffected by the sign of D parameter, that is why it is impossible to fix the sign of the D-parameter on the susceptibility data. Titiš, Krzystek, and Boča and their co-workers have recently reported that the positive sign of D signifies the angular denpendency of the zero-field splitting parameter (ZFS), as found in the present study (compounds 1 and 3). The angular distortions of the coordination polyhedra from the ideal tetrahedral geometry have been calculated for the compounds 1 and 3, that gives the distortion parameter (τ4 = 0.86) of compound 3, which is slightly greater than the distortion parameter τ4 (0.94) of compound 1. The correlation of the zero-field splitting parameter and the distortion parameter seems to be directly proportional. The more distortion from the ideal tetrahedral geometry, the greater is the D value. Probably, the higher magnitude of D value for the compound 3 compared to that of compound 1 is related to the more distortion of the Co(II) metal ion in compound 3.

elements.content: The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibly of the compound 4 was performed under a appealed field of 500 Oe over the temperature range 300–2.5 K. As shown in Figure c, the room temperature (300 K) χM T product amounts to 4.63 cm3 K mol–1, which is greater than the expected value of 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 for two isolated Co(II) ions (g = 2 and S = 3/2). By lowering the temperature, the χM T value continuously decreases up to 0.16 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.5 K. The 1/χM vs T plot has been shown in Figure S3 (). This observation indicates an antiferromagnetic interaction between the two Co(II) metal ions of the dimer unit. As shown in Figure c, there is small hump after 10 K in χM vs T plot, which is due to paramagnetic impurities. By introducing interdimer magnetic coupling constant zJ′, the magnetic susceptibility data were fitted considering the following equation which was deduced from the spin Hamiltonian. H = − 2 J S 1 · S 2 where S 1 and S 2 are the spin operators with S 1 = S 2 = 3/2 E ( S T ) = − J S T ( S T + 1 ) S T = 0 , 1 , 2 , 3. E ( S T ) = 0 , − J , − 3 J , − 6 J χ M = χ M ′ / { 1 − χ M ′ ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 β 2 ) } χ M ′ = ( 2 N g 2 β 2 / k B T ) [ A / B ] where A = [ exp ( 2 J / k B T ) + 5 ⁡ exp ( 6 J / k B T ) + 14 ⁡ exp ( 12 J / k B T ) ] B = [ 1 + 3 ⁡ exp ( 2 J / k B T ) + 5 ⁡ exp ( 6 J / k B T ) + 7 ⁡ exp ( 12 J / k B T ) ] where N is Avogadro’s number, β, the Bohr Magneton, k B, Boltzmann’s constant, g, the Lande g value. The susceptibility measurement can be well fitted across the 10–300 K temperature range and yields a g =2.21(3), and a J = −6.5(2) cm–1 and zJ′ = 0.895(7) cm–1 with agreement factor of 4.5 × 10–6 (where R = Σ[(χM T)exp–(χM T)cal]2/Σ(χM T)exp 2). As discussed before, the structure of 4 contains dimeric {(Co1)2(COO)2} unit of Co(II) ions with two chelating bidentate carboxylates groups; each Co(II) ion is further coordinated by pyridyl nitrogen of the bpim ligand and one bridging bidentate carboxylate group. Usually, in such dimers, the antiferromagnetic interactions arise between the two metal centers through carboxylate bridges, which is consistent in compound 4 as analyzed above. Previous observations of other Co(II) dimers featuring with carboxylate bridges have also shown these typical antiferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: The X-ray powder diffraction data have been recorded for all the compounds 1–4 to ensure the phase purity. The consistencies of the experimental diffraction patterns with the simulated diffraction patterns confirm the bulk homogeneity of the crystalline solids (see section 1 for the PXRD patterns of the compounds 1–4). All major peaks of the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1–4 matches well that of stimulated PXRD patterns confirming the bulk phase purity of the synthesized compounds. Although in the experimental patterns of compounds 1 and 2, few peaks are slightly broadened and shifted in comparison to those, simulated from the single-crystal data, it can still be regarded that the bulk as-synthesized materials represent compounds.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD Studies and Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

The X-ray powder diffraction data have been recorded for all the compounds 1-4 to ensure the phase purity. The consistencies of the experimental diffraction patterns with the simulated diffraction patterns confirm the bulk homogeneity of the crystalline solids (see  section 1 for the PXRD patterns of the compounds 1-4). All major peaks of the experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1-4 matches well that of stimulated PXRD patterns confirming the bulk phase purity of the synthesized compounds. Although in the experimental patterns of compounds 1 and 2, few peaks are slightly broadened and shifted in comparison to those, simulated from the single-crystal data, it can still be regarded that the bulk as-synthesized materials represent compounds.

elements.content: To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, we performed the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The relevant experiments for the crystalline samples of compounds 1–4 were performed under flowing N2 gas in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. The TGA plots for compounds are shown in the section 3 of . The TGA curves of all four compounds demonstrate the excellent thermal stability. For compound 1, the weight loss in the temperature range of 160–320 °C corresponds to the removal of the lattice water molecules. Then, it follows a significant continuous weight loss up to 550 °C attributed to the consecutive loss of ADA2– ligand and bpbix molecule. Above 650 °C, weight remains almost constant corresponding to the formation of CoO in 1, which is 9.04% (calcd. 12.7%). Compound 2 exhibits a thermal stability up to 250 °C and then the framework started collapsing up to the temperatre 750 °C because of the decomposition of the organic part of the framework. The remaining weight of 16.0% at 800 °C is expected to be for metal oxide (calcd. 14.1%). The TG analysis curve for compound 3 shows a small weight loss near 100 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the lattice H2O molecules. Upon further heating, the framework was stable up to 270 °C and then a sharp weight loss was observed between 300 and 730 °C due to the collapse of the framework. For compound 4, the decomposition begins at 350 °C followed by a sharp weight loss in two steps and ending above 700 °C. The remaining weight (18.5%) at 800 °C is accordance to the formation of metal oxide (calcd. 17.7%).

elements.content: Solid state diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of compounds 1–4 were recorded at room temperature (Figure S4, ). In case of all compounds, a broad absorption band has been observed in the region of 500–600 nm and another one in the lower energy region (near 700 nm). These both absorption peaks can be assigned to the d-d transitions of Co(II) metal ions. The higher energy band, appears in the region of 300–250 nm for all four compounds mainly because of the Π–Π* transitions from biphenyl groups of the bpbix and bpim ligands. This high energy band is comparable with the electron spectra of the corresponding bpbix/bpim free ligand (Figure S5, ).
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Properties

Solid state diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of compounds 1-4 were recorded at room temperature (Figure S4, ). In case of all compounds, a broad absorption band has been observed in the region of 500-600 nm and another one in the lower energy region (near 700 nm). These both absorption peaks can be assigned to the d-d transitions of Co(II) metal ions. The higher energy band, appears in the region of 300-250 nm for all four compounds mainly because of the Π-Π* transitions from biphenyl groups of the bpbix and bpim ligands. This high energy band is comparable with the electron spectra of the corresponding bpbix/bpim free ligand (Figure S5, ).

elements.content: Rigidity is beneficial for the targeting framework with certain topology and for the generation of porosity. Whereas, the conformational variation of the flexible linkers impact the ability to rationally design and predict the formation of extended architecture. Interexchange between rigidity and flexibility of organic ligands may lead to the several implications. In the present article, four new metal–organic coordination polymers have been reported based on the flexible and rigid analogues of adamantane based dipodal acid ligands H2ADA and H2ADC, along with two bis-imidazole linkers bpbix (flexible) and bpim (rigid). The formation of 1D metal-acid chains is directed by the geometry of carboxylate linkers (ADA2–, ADC2–) and the connectivity of 1D chains to form 2D sheets is governed by the geometry of N-donor linkers (bpbix, bpim) cooperatively, which is accountable to the final topologies/architectures. By altering the flexible and rigid parameters in the organic building blocks, the geometry of the 2D sheets has been tuned from interpenetrated 2D layers in 1 to corrugated 2D sheets in 2 and 3, and finally planar 2D sheets in 4. The compounds, discussed in this work, point out precisely the geometrical variation in the final architectures highlighting the flexibility and rigidity associated with organic building blocks. This work brings about a new focus in the area of metal–organic coordination polymers, formed from flexible as well as rigid ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Rigidity is beneficial for the targeting framework with certain topology and for the generation of porosity. Whereas, the conformational variation of the flexible linkers impact the ability to rationally design and predict the formation of extended architecture. Interexchange between rigidity and flexibility of organic ligands may lead to the several implications. In the present article, four new metal-organic coordination polymers have been reported based on the flexible and rigid analogues of adamantane based dipodal acid ligands H2ADA and H2ADC, along with two bis-imidazole linkers bpbix (flexible) and bpim (rigid). The formation of 1D metal-acid chains is directed by the geometry of carboxylate linkers (ADA2-, ADC2-) and the connectivity of 1D chains to form 2D sheets is governed by the geometry of N-donor linkers (bpbix, bpim) cooperatively, which is accountable to the final topologies/architectures. By altering the flexible and rigid parameters in the organic building blocks, the geometry of the 2D sheets has been tuned from interpenetrated 2D layers in 1 to corrugated 2D sheets in 2 and 3, and finally planar 2D sheets in 4. The compounds, discussed in this work, point out precisely the geometrical variation in the final architectures highlighting the flexibility and rigidity associated with organic building blocks. This work brings about a new focus in the area of metal-organic coordination polymers, formed from flexible as well as rigid ligands.

In the literarture, bpbix molecule was synthesized using n-butyl lithium as a base; herein we have modified the synthetic procedure by using the base NaH as shown in Scheme . bpbix was synthesized by taking sodium hydride (1.9 g, 79.1 mmol) in 10.0 mL of dry THF. Subsequently, imidazole (2.99g, 44.0 mmol), dissolved in 10.0 mL of THF, was added dropwise to NaH solution very slowly with stirring. The stirring was then continued under N2 atmosphere for 30 min. To this solution, 4,4′-bis(chloromethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl (5.02 g, 20.0 mmol) in 20.0 mL of THF was added dropwise and the resulting reaction mixture was heated at refluxing temperature for 8 h. After it was cooled down to room temperature, the solution was poured into 200.0 mL of ice cooled water and then extracted with 3 × 100.0 mL of DCM. Subsequently the DCM extract was dried with Na2SO4, followed by removal of solvent, affording the ligand bpbix in 48% yield. IR (cm–1): 3897 (w), 3743 (m), 2982 (w), 1716 (s), 1645 (m), 1608 (s), 1539 (m), 1510 (s), 1462 (m), 1369 (m), 1314 (s), 1275 (s), 1218 (s), 1168 (s),1105 (m), 1025 (s), 849 (w), 767 (m); mp 165–168 °C; 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): 7.59 (2H, s), 7.55 (4H, d), 7.25 (4H, d), 7.12 (2H, d), 6.95 (2H, d), 5.17 (4H, s). LCMS calcd for C20H18N4, 314; found, 315 [M + H]+.

Synthesis of compound {Co(ADA)(bpbix)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of CoCl2.6H2O (59.4 mg, 0.25 mmol), bpbix (78.5 mg, 0.25 mmol) and H2ADA (56.0 mg, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water and stirred for 30 min. The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 5.86 by adding 2 N NaOH solution. Then the reaction mixture was transferred to a 23 mL stainless steel Teflon lined autoclave and sealed followed by heating at 160 °C for 3 days. The resulted blue crystals were collected by filtration and characterized. Yield: 65% (based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C34H38CoN4O5 (M r = 641.61): C, 63.62%; H, 5.97%; N, 8.73%. Found: C, 63.59%; H, 5.81%; N, 8.39%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3419, 3128, 2893, 2838, 1578, 1550, 1446, 1397, 1227, 1101, 1084, 953, 805, 750, 663.

Synthesis of Compound {Co(ADC)(bpbix)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The same synthetic procedure was followed to synthesize 2 as that of 1 except H2ADA was replaced by H2ADC (56.0 mg, 0.25 mmol). The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 4.32 and heated at 130 °C for 4 days. The blue crystals were obtained after cooling to room temperature. Yield: 60% (based on Co). C32H32CoN4O4 (M r =595.55): C, 64.51%; H, 5.41%; N, 9.41%. Found: C, 64.95%; H, 5.72%; N, 9.47%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2898, 2843, 1605, 1375, 1309, 1112, 1084, 947, 827, 750, 706, 652.

Synthesis of Compound {Co(ADA)(bpim)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

To a mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (56.4 mg, 0.25 mmol), H2ADA (63.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and bpim (72.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), 10 mL of distilled water was added and stirred for 30 min. The reaction mixture was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 160 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature to obtain red crystals in 58% yield (based on Co). C32H30CoN4O5 (M r = 609.53): C, 63.03%; H, 4.96%; N, 9.19%. Found: C, 63.14%; H, 4.77%; N, 9.17%. Synthesis of Compound {Co<sub>2</sub>(ADC)<sub>2</sub>(bpim)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of CoCl2.6H2O (59.4 mg, 0.25 mmol), H2ADC (63.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and bpim (72.0 mg, 0.25 mmol) in H2O/MeOH/DMF (4:3:3) was stirred for 30 min. The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 5.68 by adding 2 N NaOH solution. The reaction mixture was transferred, sealed in 23 mL stainless steel Teflon lined autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. The red color crystals were obtained in 60% yield (based on Co).
