The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 5.86 by adding 2 N NaOH solution. Then the reaction mixture was transferred to a 23 mL stainless steel Teflon lined autoclave and sealed followed by heating at 160 °C for 3 days. The resulted blue crystals were collected by filtration and characterized. Yield: 65% (based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C34H38CoN4O5 (M r = 641.61): C, 63.62%; H, 5.97%; N, 8.73%. Found: C, 63.59%; H, 5.81%; N, 8.39%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3419, 3128, 2893, 2838, 1578, 1550, 1446, 1397, 1227, 1101, 1084, 953, 805, 750, 663.

Synthesis of Compound {Co(ADC)(bpbix)} n  (2)

The same synthetic procedure was followed to synthesize 2 as that of 1 except H2ADA was replaced by H2ADC (56.0 mg, 0.25 mmol). The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 4.32 and heated at 130 °C for 4 days. The blue crystals were obtained after cooling to room temperature. Yield: 60% (based on Co). C32H32CoN4O4 (M r =595.55): C, 64.51%; H, 5.41%; N, 9.41%. Found: C, 64.95%; H, 5.72%; N, 9.47%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2898, 2843, 1605, 1375, 1309, 1112, 1084, 947, 827, 750, 706, 652.

Synthesis of Compound {Co(ADA)(bpim)} n ⋅nH2O (3)

To a mixture of CoCl2⋅6H2O (56.4 mg, 0.25 mmol), H2ADA (63.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and bpim (72.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), 10 mL of distilled water was added and stirred for 30 min. The reaction mixture was transferred to a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 160 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature to obtain red crystals in 58% yield (based on Co). C32H30CoN4O5 (M r = 609.53): C, 63.03%; H, 4.96%; N, 9.19%. Found: C, 63.14%; H, 4.77%; N, 9.17%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3403, 3146, 2897, 2846, 1573, 1515, 1441, 1393, 1357, 1341, 1307, 1248, 1233, 1192, 1172, 1145, 1127, 1110, 1059, 1002, 961, 940, 906, 819, 772, 723.

Synthesis of Compound {Co2(ADC)2(bpim)} n  (4)

A mixture of CoCl2.6H2O (59.4 mg, 0.25 mmol), H2ADC (63.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), and bpim (72.0 mg, 0.25 mmol) in H2O/MeOH/DMF (4:3:3) was stirred for 30 min. The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 5.68 by adding 2 N NaOH solution. The reaction mixture was transferred, sealed in 23 mL stainless steel Teflon lined autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. The red color crystals were obtained in 60% yield (based on Co). C42H38Co2N4O8 (M r = 844.62): C, 59.70%; H, 4.53%; N, 6.63%. Found: C, 59.53%; H, 4.86%; N, 6.72%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3131, 2903, 2851, 1586, 1552, 1515, 1407, 1334, 1310, 1268, 1246, 1129, 1112, 1063, 1004, 962, 941, 885, 856, 842, 827, 774, 755, 733, 702.

cln_elements.content:
The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compound 1 under an applied field of 2000 Oe have been plotted as χM versus T and χM T versus T curves (Figure a). The room temperature χM T value of compound 1 is 2.71 cm3 K mol–1, which is much higher than that expected for three isolated S = 3/2 spin centers (1.875 cm3 K mol–1). As the temperature is lowered, the χM T decreases smoothly to 1.75 cm3 K mol–1 at 3.5 K. The temperature dependent nature of the magnetic susceptibility graph and the negative Weiss constant θ (= −10 K) indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of compound 1. The considerable difference between the experimental and expected room temperature χMT values indicates the existence of the spin–orbit coupling in this system. The spin–orbit coupling has been calculated by the expression for S = 3/2 systems, which accounts for spin–orbit coupling with dominant zero field splitting effects, D (eqs –) χ ∥ = ( N g 2 β 2 / k B T ) [ A / B ] where A = [ 1 + 9 ⁡ exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] and B = [ 4 ( 1 + exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] χ ⊥ = ( N g 2 β 2 / k B T ) [ C / D ] where C = [ 4 + ( 3 k B T / D ) ( 1 − exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] D = [ 4 ( 1 + exp ( − 2 D / k B T ) ] χ M ′ = [ ( χ ∥ + χ ⊥ ) / 3 ] χ M = χ M ′ / { 1 − χ M ′ ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 β 2 ) } where N is Avogadro’s number, β, the Bohr Magneton, k B, Boltzmann’s constant, g, the Lande g value, and D, the zero field splitting. The best fit has been obtained from 2–300 K with g = 1.81(2), D = 2.21(1) cm–1, and zJ′ = 0.5(6) cm–1 with agreement factor of 2.4 × 10–4. As mentioned before, the Co(II) metal ion in compound 1 has distorted tetrahedral geometry. This may be attributed to zero-field splitting (ZFS) of the 4A2 ground state with a positive sign of the D value for compound 1. According to literature for tetrahedral coordination, D values are moderate, up to around 10 cm–1.

Compound <bold>3</bold>

Temperature-dependent magnetic studies for compound 3 were performed at 2000 Oe. As shown in Figure b, the room temperature χM T value of compound 3 is 2.37 cm3 K mol–1, which is higher than the calculated spin-only value for an isolated Co(II) atom (1.875 cm3 K mol–1, S = 3/2); this is attributed to the orbital contribution arising from the distorted tetrahedral Co(II) ion. As the temperature decreases, the χM T value decreases continuously to 1.24 cm3 K mol–1 at 3.5K and 1/χ M vs T plot of this compound follows the Curie–Weiss law (see , Figure S2) with a negative Weiss constant θ= −13.10 (1) K. The observation of orbital contribution has been calculated by the eqs – as mentioned for compound 1. The best fit has been obtained with g = 1.9748(2) and D = 5.33(1) cm–1 with agreement factor of 1.82 × 10–4. In case of compound 3, a further increase in the magnitude of the D value was observed; however, there are some examples with even greater values of the D-parameter.

To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, we performed the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The relevant experiments for the crystalline samples of compounds 1–4 were performed under flowing N2 gas in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. The TGA plots for compounds are shown in the section 3 of . The TGA curves of all four compounds demonstrate the excellent thermal stability. For compound 1, the weight loss in the temperature range of 160–320 °C corresponds to the removal of the lattice water molecules. Then, it follows a significant continuous weight loss up to 550 °C attributed to the consecutive loss of ADA2– ligand and bpbix molecule. Above 650 °C, weight remains almost constant corresponding to the formation of CoO in 1, which is 9.04% (calcd. 12.7%). Compound 2 exhibits a thermal stability up to 250 °C and then the framework started collapsing up to the temperatre 750 °C because of the decomposition of the organic part of the framework. The remaining weight of 16.0% at 800 °C is expected to be for metal oxide (calcd. 14.1%). The TG analysis curve for compound 3 shows a small weight loss near 100 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the lattice H2O molecules. Upon further heating, the framework was stable up to 270 °C and then a sharp weight loss was observed between 300 and 730 °C due to the collapse of the framework. For compound 4, the decomposition begins at 350 °C followed by a sharp weight loss in two steps and ending above 700 °C. The remaining weight (18.5%) at 800 °C is accordance to the formation of metal oxide (calcd. 17.7%).
